case_name: Village Panchayat of Kanhan Pipri v. Standing Committee, Zila Parishad, Nagpur

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1375 of 1966 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1375 of 1966. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: The appeal is from the judgment and order dated October 22, 1965 of the Bombay High Court Nagpur Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated October 22, 1965 of the Bombay High Court Nagpur Bench in Special Civil Application No. 355 of 1964.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed Special Civil Application No. 355 of 1964 filed by Village Panchayat of Kanhan Pipri.

anchor.surface_text: in Special Civil Application No. 355 of 1964. N. Phadke and Naunit Lal, for the appellant. R. Agarwala and S. B. Nerkar, for respondent No. 1.

facts.text: Village Panchayat of Kanhan Pipri is the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: dismissing the petition filed under art. 226 of the Constitution by the Village Panchayat of Kanhan Pipri, appellant before us.

facts.text: Panchayat prayed for writ quashing resolution dated April 6, 1964 passed by Standing Committee, Zila Parishad, Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had in this petition prayed for the issue of a writ quashing the resolution dated April 6, 1964, passed by the Standing Committee, Zila Parishad, Nagpur

facts.text: Panchayat prayed for mandamus directing Standing Committee not to interfere with right to impose and collect octroi duty pursuant to resolution dated February 25, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: , and for a writ of mandamus directing the Standing Committee number to interfere with the right of the appellant to impose and companylect the octroi duty pursuant to its resolution dated February 25, 1963.

facts.text: Village Panchayat originally constituted under C.P. Berar Panchayat Act, 1946 (Act No. 1 of 1947).

anchor.surface_text: The Village Panchayat of Kanhan Pipri, hereinafter referred to as the Panchayat, was originally companystituted under the C.P. Berar Panchayat Act, 1946  C.P. Berar Act No. 1 of 1947 .

facts.text: Bombay Village Panchayat Act, 1958 (Bombay Act III of 1959) came into effect in Vidarbha region on June 1, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: On June 1, 1959, the Bombay Village Panchayat Act, 1958  Bombay Act III of 1959  hereinafter referred to as the Act came into effect in Vidharba region,

facts.text: Panchayat deemed to be a Panchayat under Bombay Village Panchayat Act, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: and by virtue of this Act the appellant was deemed to be a Panchayat under the Act.

facts.text: Panchayat passed resolution No. 2 on July 14, 1961 to levy octroi duty.

anchor.surface_text: On July 14, 1961, the Panchayat passed resolution No. 2 with a view to levy octroi duty.

facts.text: Resolution No. 5 passed on November 17, 1962, unanimously resolving to impose octroi duty per resolution No. 2 dated 14-7-61.

anchor.surface_text: On November 17, 1962, resolution No. 5 was passed which reads as follows The meeting companysidered the question of imposition of octroi duty.

facts.text: Public notice issued on January 26, 1963 under r. 3(b) of Maharashtra Village Panchayats Taxes and Fees Rules, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: On January 26, 1963, a public numberice was issued under r. 3 b  of the Maharashtra Village Panchayats Taxes and Fees Rules, 1960

facts.text: M/s Brooke Bond of India Pvt. Ltd. preferred objections on February 19, 1963 against proposed levy.

anchor.surface_text: hereinafter referred to as the Fees Rules. On February 19, 1963, M s Brooke Bond of India  Pr.  Ltd.- hereinafter referred to as the Company-respondent before us, preferred objections

facts.text: Panchayat passed resolution No. 3 on February 25, 1963 to levy octroi from April 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On February 25, 1963, resolution No.3 was passed. After setting out the previous resolutions and the publication of the numberice by beat of drum, and the various objections received,

facts.text: Resolution specified levy to come into force from 1-4-1963 with final publication on 1-3-1963.

anchor.surface_text: it companycludes- Having companysidered all these above objections and suggestions and having given a satisfactory explanation for the same, this Committee unanimously resolves that as per the above resolution

facts.text: Panchayat passed resolution No. 3 on March 17, 1963 fixing octroi limits, number of nakas and places.

anchor.surface_text: On March 17, 1963, resolution No. 3 was passed fixing octroi limits and number of octroi nakas and their places.

facts.text: Panchayat wrote to Collector, Nagpur on March 18, 1963 seeking approval for octroi limits and nakas.

anchor.surface_text: On March 18, 1963, the Panchayat wrote to the Collector, Nagpur, seeking his approval to the octroi limits, number of octroi nakas and their places.

facts.text: Panchayat started collecting octroi from April 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Panchayat started companylecting octroi from April 1, 1963.

facts.text: Company filed appeal on May 29, 1963 under s.124(5) before Panchayat Samiti, Parseoni.

anchor.surface_text: On May 29, 1963, the Company filed an appeal under s. 124 5  of the Act before the Panchayat Samiti, Parseoni.

facts.text: Panchayat Samiti rejected the appeal on September 4, 1963 as time-barred.

anchor.surface_text: The Panchayat Samiti, however, rejected the appeal by its resolution dated September 4, 1963. This decision was companymunicated to the Company by letter dated September 19, 1963,

facts.text: Decision communicated to Company on September 19, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: stating that the appeal has been rejected by the Samiti as per its resolution dated 4th September, 1963, because the same was number filed within limitation

facts.text: Company filed appeal to Standing Committee, Zila Parishad, Nagpur on October 22, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The Company thereupon filed an appeal before the Standing Committee, Zila Parishad, Nagpur-hereinafter, referred to as the Standing Committee-on October 22, 1963.

facts.text: Tehsildar Ramtek approved octroi limits and nakas on January 14, 1964 under r.21.

anchor.surface_text: While the appeal was pending, the Tehsildar Ramtek on January 14, 1964, approved the octroi limits and the number and location of octroi nakas

facts.text: Standing Committee allowed Company's appeal on April 6, 1964 on grounds of no prior approval of limits and tea not for consumption, use or sale.

anchor.surface_text: On April 6, 1964, the Standing Committee allowed the appeal of the Company on two grounds first, that it was necessary for the Panchayat to have the octroi limits fixed with the approval of the Collector before levying octroi under r. 21

facts.text: Standing Committee found Company not importing tea for consumption, use or sale within Panchayat limits.

anchor.surface_text: and secondly, that the Company was number importing tea within the limits of the Panchayat for companysumption, use or sale.

facts.text: High Court held Panchayat Samiti could not dismiss appeal as barred by limitation because r.5 ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the Panchayat Samiti companyld number dismiss the appeal of the Company as being barred by limitation because r. 5 of the Fees Rules was ultra vires the powers of the rule-making authority.

facts.text: High Court held octroi not validly levied as limits not fixed in accordance with law.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court further held that the octroi duty was number validly levied by the Panchayat as it had failed to fix the octroi limits in accordance with law.

facts.text: Supreme Court held octroi duty levied in accordance with law but could be collected from January 14, 1964 after approval.

anchor.surface_text: In companyclusion we hold that the octroi duty was validly levied and that it companyld be imposed and companylected with effect from January 14, 1964.

facts.text: Supreme Court held r.5 of Fees Rules not ultra vires; appeal to Samiti not time-barred.

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the question of the vires of r.5,- it seems to us that the High Court has placed a wrong interpretation on r.5.

facts.text: Supreme Court remanded case to High Court to decide if Company imported tea for consumption, use or sale within limits.

anchor.surface_text: The case is remanded to the High Court to deal with the question whether the Company imported tea for the purpose of companysumption, use or sale within the octroi limits of the Panchayat.

facts.text: Panchayat contends tea was imported for consumption, use or sale.

anchor.surface_text: that the tea was imported into the Panchayat limits for companysumption, use or sale.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal allowed; octroi valid from January 14, 1964 per resolutions of February 25, 1963 and March 17, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed, and it is declared that the Panchayat companyld validly impose octroi duty from January 14, 1964,
dismissing the petition filed under art. 226 of the Constitution by the Village Panchayat of Kanhan Pipri, appellant before us.

issues.text: the question of the validity of the levy of octroi duty

anchor.surface_text: Payment of octroi on introduction of goods, etc.-The octroi shall be paid at the octroi Naka at the time when the articles in respect of which it is leviable are imported into the octroi limits of a panchayat. Rules 30, 31, 32 and 33 deal with refund of octroi. We may first deal with the question of the validity of the levy of octroi duty.

issues.text: whether the fixing of the octroi limits with the approval of the Collector is an essential condition precedent to the levy of octroi duty

anchor.surface_text: We consider that the fixing of the octroi limits with the approval of the Collector is an essential condition precedent to the levy of octroi duty. The learned counsel for the appellant says that the approval of the Collector on January 14, 1964, relates back and, therefore, the levy of octroi from April 1, 1963, was regularised.

issues.text: whether the approval of the octroi limits on January 14, 1964, relates back to April 1, 1963

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellant says that the approval of the Collector on January 14, 1964, relates back and, therefore, the levy of octroi from April 1, 1963, was regularised. We are unable to agree with this submission. Apart from the fact that it may in certain circumstances lead to illegal levies, there is nothing in the language of r.21 which indicates that the Collector can regularise an imposition made without the authority of law.

issues.text: the question of the vires of r.5

anchor.surface_text: Coming to the question of the vires of r.5,- it seems to us that the High Court has placed a wrong interpretation on r.5. The High Court has held that as r. 5 applies to all appeals under s.124 5  of the Panchayat Act, the fixing of the commencement of the period of limitation as the date of publication of the notice under r.4 for all appeals is arbitrary and destructive of the right of appeal.

issues.text: whether the appeal of the Company to the Panchayat Samiti was barred by limitation under r.5

anchor.surface_text: the Panchayat Samiti could not dismiss the appeal of the Company as being barred by limitation because r. 5 of the Fees Rules was ultra vires

issues.text: whether the Standing Committee had jurisdiction to decide the appeal on merits

anchor.surface_text: that the Standing Committee had no jurisdiction to decide the appeal on merits as the appeal to the Panchayat Samiti was barred by limitation

issues.text: whether there was proper publication under r.4

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sen raised another point not dealt with by the High Court. He urges that there was no proper publication under r.4. We are unable to allow him to raise this point at this stage.

issues.text: whether the Company brought tea into the octroi limits of the Panchayat for consumption, use or sale therein

anchor.surface_text: The only point that remains is whether the Company brought tea into the octroi limits of the Panchayat for consumption, use or sale, therein. As we have pointed out, the High Court felt difficulty in dealing with the question because neither the Panchayat Samiti nor the Standing Committee had found sufficient facts to enable it to deal with the question.

holdings.text: the octroi duty has been levied in accordance with law

anchor.surface_text: Payment of octroi on introduction of goods, etc.-The octroi shall be paid at the octroi Naka at the time when the articles in respect of which it is leviable are imported into the octroi limits of a panchayat. Rules 30, 31, 32 and 33 deal with refund of octroi. We may first deal with the question of the validity of the levy of octroi duty. It seems to us that the octroi duty has been levied in accordance with law.

holdings.text: r.3(b) does not require the Panchayat to fix the octroi limits in the resolution passed under r.3(a)

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellant says that the approval of the Collector on January 14, 1964, relates back and, therefore, the levy of octroi from April 1, 1963, was regularised. We are unable to agree with this submission. Apart from the fact that it may in certain circumstances lead to illegal levies, there is nothing in the language of r.21 which indicates that the Collector can regularise an imposition made without the authority of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No language in r.21 for relation back; would allow illegal levies and cause confusion

holdings.text: the octroi duty was validly levied and that it could be imposed and collected with effect from January 14, 1964

anchor.surface_text: In conclusion we hold that the octroi duty was validly levied and that it could be imposed and collected with effect from January 14, 1964.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; Panchayat held entitled to impose and collect octroi duty from January 14, 1964 in accordance with resolutions dated February 25, 1963 and March 17, 1963; case remanded to High Court on factual issue whether Company imported tea for consumption, use or sale within Panchayat limits

anchor.surface_text: Payment of octroi on introduction of goods, etc.-The octroi shall be paid at the octroi Naka at the time when the articles in respect of which it is leviable are imported into the octroi limits of a panchayat. Rules 30, 31, 32 and 33 deal with refund of octroi. We may first deal with the question of the validity of the levy of octroi duty. It seems to us that the octroi duty has been levied in accordance with law.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel for the appellant says that the approval of the Collector on January 14, 1964, relates back and, therefore, the levy of octroi from April 1, 1963, was regularised. We are unable to agree with this submission. Apart from the fact that it may in certain circumstances lead to illegal levies, there is nothing in the language of r.21 which indicates that the Collector can regularise an imposition made without the authority of law.

The learned counsel for the appellant says that the approval of the Collector on January 14, 1964, relates back and, therefore, the levy of octroi from April 1, 1963, was regularised.
